Editor’s choice paper Distinctive ligand effects of functionalized magnetic microparticles immobilizing palladium acetate as heterogeneous coordination catalysts for selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone Yu Long ⁎ Ziming Zhao Li Wu Sha Luo He Wen Wei Wu Hongbo Zhang Jiantai Ma ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry (SKLAOC), Gansu Provincial Engineering Laboratory for Chemical Catalysis, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, PR China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry (SKLAOC) Gansu Provincial Engineering Laboratory for Chemical Catalysis College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Lanzhou University Lanzhou 730000 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of functionalized magnetic nanoparticles immobilizing palladium acetate with different ligands, including β-diketimine, Schiff base and (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), were prepared by a facile surface modification method. These prepared heterogeneous coordination catalysts were characterized by TEM, XRD, FT-IR, VSM, XPS and ICP. Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine was found to be an excellent scaffold for the immobilization of palladium acetate through the complexation between palladium acetate and nitrogen atoms (and oxygen atoms). Among the three catalysts, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 with the highest steric hindrance exhibited extraordinary catalytic property to undergo Wacker type reaction with a high selectivity of 94% toward the formation of acetophenone in liquid phase using H2O2 as oxidant. Meanwhile, Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2 and Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 afforded 49% and 32% selectivities of acetophenone, which were just a little higher than homogeneous Pd(OAc)2 (15%). Importantly, the proposed reaction mechanism of the styrene selective oxidation reactions by ligand immobilized Pd(OAc)2 catalyst was also inferred according to the distinctive catalytic activities of the three heterogeneous coordination catalysts and reported literatures. It could be concluded that the steric hindrance of the ligand probably played an important role in the selective oxidation of styrene, and big steric hindrance of the ligand probably was beneficial to form acetophenone. Furthermore, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 revealed high efficiency and stability during recycling stages. Keywords Ligand effect Heterogeneous coordination catalysts Selective oxidation Styrene Acetophenone 1 Introduction The palladium(II)-catalyzed oxidation of terminal olefins to methyl ketones, known as the Tsuji−Wacker oxidation, is one of the most important reactions that have extensive synthetic applications in laboratories and industries [1–10]. Acetophenones, as significant intermediates for the manufacture of a variety of chemical products such as pesticides, perfumes, pharmaceuticals and resins, can be reasonably obtained by palladium(II)-catalyzed oxidation of styrene [10–16]. Classically, the reaction is conducted with PdCl2 and CuCl as homogeneous catalyst under aerobic atmosphere [2]. However, it suffers from palladium decomposition, chlorinated by-products, copper waste and expensive cost, which has been recognized as significant limitations [17,18]. In addition, the selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone is often accompanied with other problems, such as difficulties in the product separation, low selectivity, uses of acetic acid and CuCl2 to promote the reoxidation of Pd(0) into highly active Pd(II) resulting in the corrosion hazards of the reactor [15,19]. Many catalytic systems have been developed to solve these major drawbacks for the selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone, such as avoiding copper(II) salts [19], using various alternative solvent [20–23], using ionic liquids [13,24], and using supported catalysts [20,25,26]. Among the heterogeneous catalytic systems, Zhao et al. have reported an efficient green catalyst for selective oxidation of styrene with H2O2 as oxidizing agent [15]. In Zhao’s work, periodic mesoporous organosilica supported β-Diketimine was used as a scaffold for immobilization of palladium acetate. As we all know, a variety of organic ligands, such as silane coupling agent containing nitrogen, Salen ligands and Schiff base, also can be used to immobilize palladium acetate to form supported Pd(OAc)2 catalyst. How will their catalytic activities be compared with β-Diketimine? On the other hand, since the traditional heterogeneous catalysts are readily dispersed in liquid media by Brownian motion, the separation process of catalysts is still a big challenge. This issue can be solved by using a magnetic material such as Fe3O4, so as to be separated by an external magnetic field. Furthermore, the surface of Fe3O4 microparticles can be improved by coating chemically modified shells [27–39]. Silica is the most popular inorganic coating material for Fe3O4, because it very easily binds to Fe3O4 [30–32]. Silica as the coating shell improves the water solubility and biocompatibility of Fe3O4. Importantly, the dense silica shell has plenty of Si–OH groups for potential derivatization with various functional units allowing the introduction of catalytic molecules into Fe3O4 [35]. Herein, different ligands, including β-diketimine, Schiff base and APTES, were used to functionalize magnetic microparticles and immobilize palladium acetate with a facile surface modification method. The immobilization abilities and stabilities of active sites in the three heterogeneous coordination catalysts were tested with a facile experiment. And the proposed mechanism of the distinctive ligand effects for Wacker reaction was inferred. To our best knowledge, ligand effects on magnetic core-shell material for catalytic reaction have not been reported. Moreover, the recycling performances of these catalysts were also determined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Iron(III) chloride hydrate, sodium acetate, ethylene glycol, trisodium citrate, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), Palladium(II) acetate, acetylacetone, 4-aminophenol, hydrochloric acid (36%), tetrahydrofuran, diethylenetriamine, salicylaldehyde, triethylamine, acetonitrile, methylbenzene, styrene, ethanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), 3-isocyanatopropyltriethoxysilane, chloropropyltrimethoxysilane were purchased from Alfa Aesar. All chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification except tetrahydrofuran and methylbenzene. Deionized water was used throughout the experiments. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The preparation process of Fe3O4@SiO2-Pd(OAc)2 catalysts were shown in Scheme 1 . And the specific process of preparation was listed as follows. 2.2.1 Synthesis of magnetite Fe3O4 microparticles The water dispersible Fe3O4 microparticles were prepared according to the reported method previously [40]. Briefly, FeCl3·6H2O (3.25g), sodium acetate (NaAc, 6.0g) and trisodium citrate (1.3g) were dissolved in ethylene glycol (100mL). After vigorous stirring, the mixture would become yellow solution, which was then transferred and sealed into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (250mL in capacity). The autoclave was heated at 200°C for 10h, and then allowed to cool down to room temperature. The black products were washed with deionized water and ethanol for 3 times, respectively. 2.2.2 Synthesis of magnetic Fe3O4@SiO2 composite The core-shell Fe3O4@SiO2 microspheres were prepared through a versatile Stöber sol-gel method as follows [41]. Fe3O4 magnetite microparticles (150mg) was dissolved in the mixture solution of ethanol (280mL), deionized water (70mL) and concentrated ammonia solution (5.0mL, 28wt%). Afterward, 3.0mL of TEOS was added dropwise under vigorous stirring in 10min, and the mixture was allowed to proceed for 10h at room temperature under continuous mechanical stirring. The resultant core-shell Fe3O4@SiO2 microsphere products were separated and collected with a magnet, followed by washing with deionized water and ethanol for 3 times, respectively [42]. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Fe3O4@SiO2-Pd(OAc)2 catalysts with different ligands 2.2.3.1 Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 Firstly, β-diketimine was synthesized according to a reported method [15]. In a typical synthesis, acetylacetone (1.0g, 10mmol) and 4-aminophenol (2.2g, 20mmol) were dissolved in absolute ethanol (50mL) in around bottom flask (100mL) containing a magnetic stir bar. HCl (36%, 0.5g) was added into the mixture solution. After the reaction mixture was refluxed for 3 days, the mixture was cooled down to room temperature and treated with water (20mL) containing Na2CO3. The solution was extracted with dichloromethane for three times (20mL each). The organic layer was dried through MgSO4 and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The solid product was washed with cold ethanol and dried under vacuum to give β-diketimine. The 1H NMR of the resultant β-diketimine was shown in Supporting information (Fig. S1). Secondly, in a typical synthesis of β-diketimine ligand, synthesized β-diketimine (1.0g, 3.5mmol) was dissolved in dry THF (50mL) under N2 in a two-necked round bottom flask equipped with a condenser. 3-Isocyanatopropyltriethoxysilane (1.8g, 7.0mmol) was then added dropwise to the solution over 30min. After the reaction mixture was refluxed for 24h, it was cooled down to room temperature. THF was removed in vacuo, leaving a highly viscous liquid. Hexane was added to the viscous liquid, and the precipitates were formed to afford β-diketiminatobis(4,1-phenylene) bis(3-triethoxysilylpropylcarbamate). The 1H NMR of the resultant product was shown in Supporting information (Fig. S2). Thirdly, 0.5g Fe3O4@SiO2 microspheres were suspended in 100ml toluene solution, then, 1.0g of the prepared β-diketimine ligand was added under dry nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was refluxed for 24h and the resulted solid was magnetically separated, washed with ethanol to remove the unreacted residue of silylating reagent. The obtained Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine was vacuum dried in vacuum at 60°C for 12h. Finally, an aqueous solution of Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine (500mg) in acetone (50mL) was ultrasonicated for 1h to form a uniform suspension. Subsequently, Pd(OAc)2-acetone (20mg, 20mL) solution was added to the suspension with vigorous stirring. And then the solution was stirred at room temperature for 24h. The product was collected from the solution by an external magnet and washed with deionized water and ethanol. The step was repeated several times before drying in vacuum at 60°C for 12h. 2.2.3.2 Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2 Firstly, the Schiff base ligand (N,N′-bis(3-salicylidenaminopropyl)amine) was prepared by adding one molecular equivalent of diethylenetriamine to two molecular equivalent of salicylaldehyde dissolved in ethanol at room temperature. After stirring for 15min, the volume of the solution was reduced until only an oil remained [43]. Secondly, 0.5g Fe3O4@SiO2 microspheres were suspended in 100ml toluene solution, then, 1.0g of chloropropyltrimethoxysilane was added under dry nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was refluxed for 24h and the resulted solid was magnetically separated, washed with ethanol to remove the unreacted residue of silylating reagent. The obtained Fe3O4@SiO2-Cl was vacuum dried in vacuum at 60°C for 12h. Thirdly, 0.5g of Fe3O4@SiO2-Cl was suspended in 100ml of acetonitrile with sonication. To this mixture was added 250mg of Schiff base ligand and 0.2ml of triethylamine and the resulted mixture was refluxed for 12h. The resultant solid was separated magnetically and then washed with ethanol several times to remove the unreacted residue of the Schiff base ligand and dried in vacuum at 60°C for 12h. Finally, an aqueous solution of Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base (500mg) in acetone (50mL) was ultrasonicated for 1h to form a uniform suspension. Subsequently, Pd(OAc)2-acetone (20mg, 20mL) solution was added to the suspension with vigorous stirring. And then the solution was stirred at room tempereture for 24h. The product was collected from the solution by an external magnet and washed with deionized water and ethanol. The step was repeated several times before drying in vacuum at 60°C for 12h. 2.2.3.3 Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 0.5g Fe3O4@SiO2 microspheres were suspended in 100ml toluene solution, then, 1.0g of APTES was added under dry nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was refluxed for 24h and the resulted solid was magnetically separated, washed with ethanol to remove the unreacted residue of silylating reagent. The obtained Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES was vacuum dried in vacuum at 60°C for 12h. Then, an aqueous solution of Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES (500mg) in acetone (50mL) was ultrasonicated for 1h to form a uniform suspension. Subsequently, Pd(OAc)2-acetone (20mg, 20mL) solution was added to the suspension with vigorous stirring. And then the solution was stirred at room tempereture for 24h. The product was collected from the solution by an external magnet and washed with deionized water and ethanol. The step was repeated several times before drying in vacuum at 60°C for 12h. 2.3 Characterizations of catalysts These magnetic micro-materials were characterized by inductively coupled plasma (ICP), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) and vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM). XRD measurements were performed on a Rigaku D/max-2400 diffractometer using Cu–Ka radiation as the X-ray source in the 2θ range of 5–80°. The size and morphology of the magnetic microparticles were observed by a Tecnai G2 F30 transmission electron microscope and samples were obtained by placing a drop of a colloidal solution onto a copper grid and evaporating the solvent in air at room temperature. Pd content of the catalyst was measured by ICP on IRIS Advantage analyzer. Magnetic measurements of the three catalysts were investigated with a Quantum Design VSM at room temperature in an applied magnetic field sweeping from −8 to 8 kOe. XPS was recorded on a PHI-5702 instrument and the C1s line at 284.8eV was used as the binding energy reference. 2.4 Typical procedure for the selective oxidation of styrene In a typical experiment, styrene (104mg, 1mmol) was added to an DMSO solvent (10mL) containing Fe3O4@SiO2-Pd(OAc)2 (Pd, 0.01mmol) as catalyst. In order to avoid immediate decomposition of H2O2 and its strong effervescence, 30% H2O2 (340mg, 3mmol) was added slowly to the mixture solution over a period of 3h. The resulting mixture was stirred under 400rpm at 60°C for 6h. The product was analyzed qualitatively using gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts As shown in Fig. 1 a, the average diameter of the as-synthesized Fe3O4@SiO2 microparticles was about 200nm and a continuous layer of SiO2 could be observed on the outer shell of the Fe3O4 microsphere cores and the thickness was about 60nm. The resultant Fe3O4@SiO2 composites had good dispersibility and spherical morphology. Fig. 1b–d were the TEM images of Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2, respectively. It could be easily revealed that after grafting silane coupling agents and fastening Pd(OAc)2, no changes of the morphology of these microparticles had occurred, and none of Pd or PdOx nanoparticles were observed in Fig. 1b–d. In order to give powerful evidence of the existence of PdⅡ in the catalysts, EDX spectra of Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 was presented in Fig. 2 a–c. The peak of copper (Cu) arised from Cu grid in TEM analysis. The peaks corresponding to Pd were expressly found in the EDX spectra. In addition, EDX spectra of Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine was characterized to make comparison of before and after palladium addition (Fig. 2d). By comparison, it could be determined that the palladium is immobilized on the surface of the microparticles by these binding ligands. The crystallinity and phase composition of the resulting products were investigated by XRD. Fig. 3 showed the wide angle XRD patterns of the samples. As shown in Fig. 3a (Fe3O4@SiO2), all the peaks at 2θ>30° were in agreement with cubic inverse spinel Fe3O4 (JCPDS card No. 82-1533). There is abroad diffraction peak at 2θ<30° assigned to amorphous silica coated on the surface of Fe3O4 nanospheres [44]. It is observed that the diffraction peaks basically do not change in Fig. 3b–d. In the XRD pattern of the three prepared catalysts, characteristic diffraction peaks indexed to the Pd(0) could not be observed, which suggested the excellent stability of Pd(OAc)2 through the complexation with the three different ligands. The compositions of these composite microspheres were confirmed by FT-IR (Fig. 4 ). As was also shown in the figure, in the low-frequency region, the peaks around 580–590cm−1 (Fig. 4a–d), corresponded to the stretching vibration peak of Fe-O. The Si–O–Si bands around 1650, 1100, 800 and 450cm−1 associated with the formation of a condensed silica network were present in the four spectra. The presence of broad bands at around 3000–2800cm−1 implied the aliphatic C–H stretching vibration attributed to alkyl chains. The bands around 1600cm−1 were attributed to the bending vibrations of the connection on the surface amino group [45]. From the spectrogram, the peaks from 1300cm−1 to 1700cm−1 in Fig. 4d provided powerful evidence in support of the formation of β-diketiminato-acetate Pd2+ complex [15]. The XPS elemental survey scan of Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 and Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2 was showed in Fig. 5 a and b, respectively. Peaks corresponding to iron, silicon, oxygen, nitrogen, palladium and carbon were clearly observed. To ascertain the oxidation state of the Pd, XPS studies were carried out. The XPS analysis of the two Pd2+ catalysts was showed in Fig. 5c and d. As expected, the spectrum of the Pd 3d region confirmed the presence of Pd2+ with peak binding energy of 338.8 and 344eV, which were assigned to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2, respectively. Since the ability of recoverability was important for this catalyst, magnetic measurements were performed using a VSM at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 6 , Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 showed small reduction of the saturation magnetization. This slightly reduction of the saturation magnetization for the material loaded solid was expected. The measured saturation magnetizations were 16.6emug−1 for Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 (Fig. 6b), 15.5emug−1 for Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2 (Fig. 6c) and 14.9emug−1 for Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 (Fig. 6d). The decrease of the saturation magnetization suggested the presence of silane coupling agent and Pd(OAc)2 on the surface of the magnetic support. Even with this reduction in the saturation magnetization, the catalyst could still be efficiently separated from solution with an external magnet as shown in the inset image in Fig. 6. In addition, elemental analysis (EA) was used to verify the presence of C, N, and H in the catalyst precursors. Meanwhile, Pd content of the catalyst was measured by ICP on IRIS advantage analyzer. As shown in Table 1 , after the first step, three kinds of silane coupling agents were successfully attached to the Fe3O4@SiO2 because of the presence of the corresponding percentages of C, N, and H. Pd(OAc)2 then “reacted” with the terminal amino group of to form the Pd-coordination complex. The corresponding percentages of C, N, and H in the Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 were detected in accordance with Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine, Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base, Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES2. As expected, the C/Pd (mol) was 7.07, 31.23, and 34.93, which revealed that Pd-coordination complexes were successfully existent. It should be noted that the lower C/Pd in Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 might be caused by the monodentate ligand (one terminal amino group of APTES). In order to testify the stabilities of the Pd(OAc)2 complex structure of these three catalysts, a facile experiment was designed and tested. Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2, Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2, and Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 were dispersed in different solvents with the same quantity of Pd and the same volume of solvent. Then the mixture was stirred under 400rpm at 60°C for 6h (this condition was the same with the Wacker reaction test in this paper), respectively. After filtration process, the leaching weight percentage of Pd in the solution part was determined by ICP analysis. As shown in Table 2 , Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 always leached the least Pd after stirring 6h at different solvents at 60°C. And Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2 also exhibited much better stability than Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 in this stability test. Therefore, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine and Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base were excellent scaffolds for the immobilization of palladium acetate through the complexation between palladium acetate and nitrogen atoms (and oxygen atoms), leading to the formation of stable heterogeneous catalysts. On the other hand, it could be easily observed that the polarity of the solvent had significant influence for the leaching weight percentage of Pd in the solution part, and palladium seemed to tend to leach in high polarity solvent. As shown in entry 7, leaching weight percentage of Pd in H2O was much less than in other solvents, which might be caused by that Pd(OAc)2 was insoluble in water. 3.2 Catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of styrene The ligand effects of these heterogeneous coordination catalysts with the same active center (Pd(OAc)2) for the selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone were evaluated. Firstly, in order to explore the optimal reaction conditions, including reaction temperature, reaction time, solvent and oxidant, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 was chosen to catalyze the selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone. As shown in Table 3 , the yields of the target product (acetophenone) catalyzed by Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 were low at 20°C and 40°C (Table 3, entry 1–2). When the temperature was increased to 60°C, highest yield of acetophenone (66.7%) was obtained (Table 3, entry 2). However, when the temperature was increased to 80°C, the selectivity of acetophenone and the yield of acetophenone reduced to 36% and 29.9% though the conversion showed a little bit higher. It revealed the suitable temperature for the production of acetophenone was 60°C, and higher temperature was beneficial to produce more by-products, such as benzaldehyde and benzoic acid (Table 3, entry 4). Therefore, 60°C was chosen as the optimum reaction temperature. Meanwhile, the optimum reaction was 6h, due to longer reaction time couldn’t increase the yield of acetophenone (Table 3, entry 5–8). According to that the catalytic activities in different solvents, it was easily found that the polarity of the solvent had a significant impact on the conversion and selectivity. And with the decrease of the polarity of the solvent, the yield of acetophenone decreased obviously except H2O (Table 3, entry 9–14). Though Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 showed worse stability in DMSO than other solvents (as shown in Table 2), Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 exhibited much higher yield than other solvents. Thus, DMSO was chosen as the optimized solvent. Under the optimized reaction temperature time and solvent, oxidant was examined. As shown in Table 3, entry 15, O2 was not a desired oxidant though it exhibited an outstanding selectivity of acetophenone. The obtained results (Table 3, entry 3, 16, 17) indicated that the conversion rate increased quite remarkably when the ratio of H2O2:styrene increased, showing the conversion enhancement from 60% for a ratio of 2:1 to 82% for a ratio of 4:1. A highest selectivity of 94% for the acetophenone production was observed when the H2O2:styrene was 3:1. Furthermore, the selectivity of acetophenone decreased to 78% for the H2O2:styrene of 4:1. Therefore, the optimized reaction conditions are: 60°C, 6h, DMSO, and H2O2:styrene of 3:1. Table 4 listed the different catalytic performances of Fe3O4@SiO2-Pd(OAc)2 catalysts in the selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone. As shown in Table 4, these catalysts precursor without Pd did not perform any catalytic activities (Table 4, entry 2, 3, 5, 7). All of these catalysts containing Pd(OAc)2 revealed well catalytic conversions of styrene, especially the homogeneous Pd(OAc)2 (Table 4, entry 4, 6, 8, 9). However, the homogeneous Pd(OAc)2 exhibited the lowest selectivity of acetophenone, which demonstrated that homogeneous Pd(OAc)2 was a fine catalyst for the oxidation of styrene rather than a fine catalyst for the selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone. In contrast, the three supported Fe3O4@SiO2-Pd(OAc)2 catalysts increased the selectivities of acetophenone. Importantly, the reaction with Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 took place at 60°C for 6h gave a highest selectivity of acetophenone (94%, Table 4, entry1). As we all know, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 has the most serious steric hindrance for the active site–Pd(OAc)2. Interestingly, with the most serious steric hindrance, it showed the best catalytic property for the selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone. In order to account for this result, according to the reaction mechanisms proposed in the literature [15,46,47] and combining with the results in Tables 3 and 4, the proposed reaction mechanism was inferred in Scheme 2 . This mechanism scheme was similar with previous, however we came up with a more particular and distinguishing exposition as followed. Firstly, in the step 1, immobilized Pd2+ formed a palladium hydroperoxidic species by the addition of H2O2. This species was responsible for transferring oxygen to the styrene through a pseudocyclic hydroperoxypalladation process of the coordinated olefin (step 2). Secondly, intermediate product was faced with two competition processes, that was step 3 and step 6 as shown in Scheme 2. This competition process was mainly determined by the steric hindrance between intermediate and hydroperoxypalladation. And the steric hindrance of the ligand probably played an important role in the selective oxidation of styrene. As we all know, styrene could be easily oxidized to styrene oxide in the presence of H2O2 and active palladium species, to process step 6 in Scheme 2. And with the small steric hindrance of the ligand, hydroperoxypalladation was likely to accomplish the further nucleophilic attack, leading to the formations of benzaldehyde (or benzoic acid after further oxidation) and palladium hydroxyl species, and completing another catalytic cycle (step 6-8). However, the big steric hindrance between intermediate and hydroperoxypalladation would prevent the further nucleophilic attack to process step 7. Therefore, with the big steric hindrance of the ligand, hydroperoxypalladation was more likely to link with β-C to process step 3 and step 4, leading to the formations of acetophenone and palladium hydroxyl species. In the presence of an additional H2O2, this palladium hydroxyl species regenerated the palladium hydroperoxidic species, completing the catalytic cycle (step 5). This possible reaction mechanism was consistent with the experimental data. As shown in Table 3, entry 4, 6, 8, 9, Pd(OAc)2 without steric hindrance of the ligand obtained the highest conversion and lowest yield of acetophenone. Meanwhile, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 consist of a complex ligand with big steric hindrance showed a low catalytic conversion and the highest selectivity and yield of acetophenone. 3.3 Recyle Furthermore, we investigated the recyclability of Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2. After the first cycle of the reaction, the catalyst was recovered with the help of a magnet, successively washed with distilled water (to remove excess of H2O2), ethanol, and dried at room temperature ready for the next cycle. New catalyst will be added if the recovered catalyst is not enough. The selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone catalyzed by recycled catalyst was displayed in Fig. 7 . After five times cycles, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 still maintained high activity with an acceptable decrease of conversion. Especially, the selectivity of acetophenone remained about the same during recycling stages. The weight percentage of Pd in Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 after five times cycles, determined by ICP analysis, was 2.0%, affording Pd losses of 9.1%. It could be concluded that the PdⅡ of Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 was well stable. 4 Conclusion In summary, Pd(OAc)2 was successfully immobilized onto Fe3O4@SiO2 with β-diketimine, Schiff base and APTES by a facile surface modification method, respectively. Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine was found to be the best efficient scaffold for the immobilization of palladium acetate through the complexation between palladium acetate and nitrogen atoms (and oxygen atoms). Among these three heterogeneous coordination catalysts, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 exhibited extraordinary catalytic property to undergo Wacker type reaction with a high selectivity of 94% toward the formation of acetophenone, which was much higher than Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2 (49%) and Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 (32%). And the proposed reaction mechanism of the styrene selective oxidation reactions by heterogeneous Pd(OAc)2 based catalyst was also inferred according to the different catalytic activities of these three heterogeneous coordination catalysts and other reported mechanisms. It could be concluded that the steric hindrance of the ligand probably played an important role in the selective oxidation of styrene, and big steric hindrance of the ligand probably was beneficial to form acetophenone. Furthermore, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 revealed high efficiency and stability during recycling stages. In this paper, it was determined that distinctive ligand effects of supported palladium acetate catalysts for selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone certainly existed. We envisaged that our work demonstrated an acceptable reason for distinctive ligand effects in ligand functionalized heterogeneous catalysts. It could enable further implications in a number of other heterogeneous catalytic systems as well. coredata.dc:description: A series of functionalized magnetic nanoparticles immobilizing palladium acetate with different ligands, including β-diketimine, Schiff base and (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES), were prepared by a facile surface modification method. These prepared heterogeneous coordination catalysts were characterized by TEM, XRD, FT-IR, VSM, XPS and ICP. Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine was found to be an excellent scaffold for the immobilization of palladium acetate through the complexation between palladium acetate and nitrogen atoms (and oxygen atoms). Among the three catalysts, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 with the highest steric hindrance exhibited extraordinary catalytic property to undergo Wacker type reaction with a high selectivity of 94% toward the formation of acetophenone in liquid phase using H2O2 as oxidant. Meanwhile, Fe3O4@SiO2-Schiff base-Pd(OAc)2 and Fe3O4@SiO2-APTES-Pd(OAc)2 afforded 49% and 32% selectivities of acetophenone, which were just a little higher than homogeneous Pd(OAc)2 (15%). Importantly, the proposed reaction mechanism of the styrene selective oxidation reactions by ligand immobilized Pd(OAc)2 catalyst was also inferred according to the distinctive catalytic activities of the three heterogeneous coordination catalysts and reported literatures. It could be concluded that the steric hindrance of the ligand probably played an important role in the selective oxidation of styrene, and big steric hindrance of the ligand probably was beneficial to form acetophenone. Furthermore, Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 revealed high efficiency and stability during recycling stages.
coredata.dc:title: Distinctive ligand effects of functionalized magnetic microparticles immobilizing palladium acetate as heterogeneous coordination catalysts for selective oxidation of styrene to acetophenone
